alternative_title: Business travel: reporting expenses and benefits
overview: If your business provides transport expenses for employees - what you must report to HMRC and taxes and National Insurance due
title: Expenses and benefits: travel

table.body:
As an employer paying your employees' travel costs, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

This includes costs for:

- providing travel
- reimbursing travel
- meals and other ‘subsistance’ while travelling
- accommodation (if your employee needs to stay away overnight)

^There are different rules for reporting expenses relating to [public transport](/expenses-and-benefits-public-transport "expenses relating to public transport").^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
##Business travel you provide, pay for or reimburse

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, you won’t need to report or pay.

Business journeys are either:

+ journeys that are part of your employees duties, eg a service engineer travelling to an appointment
+ journeys an employee has to make to get to a temporary workplace

%If you pay more than the cost of the travel, you’ll have to [report the expense](/expenses-and-benefits-travel/what-to-report-and-pay "report the expense").%

##Private travel

If you arrange and pay for the travel, and your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, you won’t need to report or pay.

You’ll be exempt from reporting or paying anything for all employees and directors if the cost is for:

+ [a works bus service](/expenses-and-benefits-works-bus-services "Works bus services: reporting expenses and benefits")
+ an [employee with a disability](/expenses-and-benefits-items-for-disabled-employees "Items for disabled employees: reporting expenses and benefits") (but only in certain circumstances)
+ a taxi home after occasional and irregular late-night working
+ a taxi home if a car-sharing system is temporarily unavailable
+ [bicycles or cycle safety equipment](/expenses-and-benefits-bikes-for-employees "Bikes for employees: reporting expenses and benefits")
+ travelling to work because public transport has been disrupted by industrial action


*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If your employees' travel isn't [exempt](/work-travel-reporting-expenses-and-benefits/what-is-exempt "Work travel and your employees (What is exempt)") you must report it to HMRC and may have to deduct or pay tax and National Insurance on it.

##Business travel

^You can apply for a [dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "dispensation"), which means you won’t have to include business travel expenses on your end-of-year reports.^

If you don't have a dispensation, you should report in the following way:

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year | Report on form P11D, section K, B or N | Nothing
Directors | Report on form P11D, section K, B or N | Nothing

###Reimbursing more than the necessary costs

If you reimburse your employee with more than the necessary costs of their business travel, the extra amount counts as earnings, so: 

- add it to your employee's other earnings
- deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

^If you've agreed with HMRC that this will be a [scale rate payment](/expenses-and-benefits-cash-sum-payments/scale-rate-payments "scale rate payments"), you won't need to report it.^

##Private travel

All non-business travel is counted as private. This includes the journey between an employee's home and permanent workplace. 

###You arrange the transport and pay for it

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or for directors, you should:

- report on form P11D, section B
- add the cost of the transport to the employee's other earnings and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll

###Your employee arranges it and you pay the transport supplier directly

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year | Add it to P11D | Add the cost of the transport to the employee's other earnings and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Directors | Report on form P11D | Add the cost of the transport to the employee's other earnings and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll

###Your employee arranges it and you pay the supplier directly

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year | Fill in form P9D, section A(2) | Add the cost of the transport to the employee's other earnings and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year | Fill in form P11D, section B | Add the cost of the transport to the employee's other earnings and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Directors | Fill in form P11D, section B | Add the cost of the transport to the employee's other earnings and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll

###Your employee arranges and pays for the transport, and you reimburse them

The money you pay them counts as earnings, so: 

- add it to your employee's other earnings
- deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll


*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
